user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtBinFile2Mem:
```c
bool UtBinFile2Mem(void *Memory, const char *Filename, uint32 Length)
{
    FILE *fp;
    bool  Success;

    Success = false;
    if ((fp = fopen(Filename, "r")))
    {
        if (fread(Memory, Length, 1, fp) == 1)
        {
            Success = true;
        }
        fclose(fp);
    }
    else
    {
        UtAssert_Failed("UtBinFile2Mem: Error Opening %s: %s", Filename, strerror(errno));
    }

    return Success;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function UtBinFile2Mem:
#define UtAssert_Failed(__VA_ARGS__) UtAssertEx(false,UtAssert_GetContext(),__FILE__,__LINE__,__VA_ARGS__)
...
UtAssert_CaseType_t UtAssert_GetContext(void)
{
    return DefaultContext;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if ((fp = fopen(Filename, "r")))
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown code: UtBinFile2Mem calls the standard library function fopen which does not call UtBinFile2Mem, so there is no direct or indirect self-call. A concrete violation scenario would be if fopen were redefined or implemented to call UtBinFile2Mem (for example via a macro #define fopen(...) UtBinFile2Mem(...) or a custom fopen implementation that calls UtBinFile2Mem), producing indirect recursion UtBinFile2Mem -> fopen -> UtBinFile2Mem.
